sp.p: Yes, now I can answer with a safe Conscience, as to that point, all the rest may be Art Magick; but, as for the Diamonds, here they are, under safe custody.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Then what are these upon my Arm? To Sosia.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Flints, or Pebbles, or some such Trumpery of enchanted Stones.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: They say the proof of a true Diamond is to glitter in the dark; I think my Master had best take my Lady into some By-corner, and try whose Diamond will sparkle best.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Yet now I think on't, Madam, did not a certain Friend of mine present 'em to you?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: What Friend?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Why another Sosia; one that made himself Sosia in my despight, and also unsociated me.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Sirrah, leave your nauseous Nonsense: break open the Seal, and take out the Diamonds

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: More words than one to a Bargain, Sir; I thank you: That's no part of prudence for me to commit Burglary upon the Seals: Do you look first upon the Signet, and tell me in your Conscience, whether the Seals be not as firm as when you clapt the Wax upon them.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: The Signature is firm. Looking.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Then take the Signature into your own custody, and open it; for I will have nothing done at my proper peril. Giving him the Casket.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! Here's nothing, but an empty space; the Nest where they were laid. Breaking open the Seal.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Then if the Birds are flown, the Fault's not mine; here has been fine conjuring work; or else the Jewel, knowing to whom it shou'd be given, took occasion to steal out, by a natural instinct, and ty'd it self upon that pretty Arm.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Can this be possible!

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Yes, very possible: You, my Lord Amphitryon, may have brought forth another You my Lord Amphitryon, as well as I Sosia have brought forth another Me Sosia. and our Diamonds may have procreated these Diamonds; and so we are all three double,

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: If this be true, I hope my Goblet has gigg'd another Golden Goblet: and then they may carry double upon all four. Aside.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: My Lord, I have stood silent, out of wonder
What you cou'd wonder at.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: A chilling Sweat, a damp of Jealousie, Aside.
Hangs on my Brows, and clams upon my Limbs.
I fear; and yet I must be satisfied:
And, to be satisfy'd, I must dissemble.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Why muse you so, and murmur to your self?
If you repent your Bounty, take it back-

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Not so: but, if you please, relate what past,
At our last Enterview.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: That Question wou'd infer you were not here.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I say not so;
I only wou'd refresh my memory;
And have my Reasons to desire the Story.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: So: This is as good sport for me as an Examination of a great Belly before a Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: The Story is not long: you know I met you,
Kiss'd you, and prest you close within my Arms,
With all the tenderness of Wively Love.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I cou'd have spar'd that Kindness. Aside.
And what did I? To her.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You strain'd me with a Masculine Embrace;
As you wou'd squeeze my Soul out.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Did I so?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: You did.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Confound those Arms that were so kind— Aside.
Proceed, proceed.— To her.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: You wou'd not stay to sup; but, much complaining of your drowsiness, and want of natural Rest—

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Made haste to Bed: Ha, was't not so? Go on— Aside.
And stab me with each Syllable thou speak'st.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: So, now 'tis coming, now 'tis coming.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: I have no more to say.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Why, went we not to Bed?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Why not?
Is it a Crime for Husband and for Wife
To go to Bed, My Lord?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Perfidious Woman!

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Ungrateful Man!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: She justifies it too!

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: I need not justifie: Of what am I accus'd?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Of all that prodigality of Kindness,
Giv'n to another, and usurp'd from me.
So bless me Heav'n, if since my first departure,
I ever set my foot upon this Threshold.
So am I innocent of all those Joys,
And dry of those Embraces.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Then I, it seems, am false?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: As surely false, as what thou say'st is true.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I have betray'd my Honour, and my Love?
And am a foul Adultress?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: What thou art,
Thou stand'st condemn'd to be, by thy Relation.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Go, thou unworthy Man; for ever go:
No more my Husband; go thou base Impostour;
Who tak'st a vile pretence to taint my Fame;
And, not content to leave, wouldst ruine me.
Enjoy thy wish'd Divorce: I will not plead
My Innocence, of this pretended Crime:
I need not; spet thy Venom; do thy worst:
But know, the more thou wou'dst expose my Vertue,
Like purest Linen laid in open Air,
'Twill bleach the more, and whiten to the view.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: 'Tis well thou art prepar'd for thy Divorce:
For, know thou too, that after this Affront,
This foul Indignity, done to my Honour,
Divorcement is but petty Reparation:
But, since thou hast, with Impudence affirm'd
My false Return, and brib'd my Slaves to vouch it,
The Truth shall, in the face of Thebes be clear'd;
Thy Unkle, the Companion of my Voyage,
And all the Crew of Sea-men, shall be brought,
Who were embark'd, and came with me to Land;
Nor parted, till I reach'd this cursed Door:
So shall this Vision of my late Return,
Stand a detected Lye; and woe to those
Who thus betray'd my Honour.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Sir, Shall I wait on you?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: No, I will go alone: Expect me here. Exit Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: Please you— that I— To Alcmena.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Oh! Nothing now can please me:
Darkness, and Solitude, and Sighs, and Tears,
And all th'inseparable Train of Grief,
Attend my Steps for ever— Exit Alcmena.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: What if I shou'd lye now, and say we have been here before? I never saw any good that came of telling truth. Aside.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: He makes no more Advances to me: I begin a little to suspect, that my Gold Goblet will prove but Copper. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis resolv'd, I will lye abominably, against the Light of my own Conscience. For suppose the tother Sosia has been here: perhaps that strong Dog has not only beaten me, but also has been predominant upon my Wife, and most carnally misus'd her! Now, by asking certain Questions of her, with a Side-Wind, I may come to understand how Squares go; and whether my Nuptial Bed be violated. Aside.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Most certainly he has learn'd Impudence of his Master; and will deny his being here: but that shall not serve his turn, to cheat me of my Present!— Aside. Why Sosia! What, in a brown Study?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: A little cogitabund, or so; concerning this dismal Revolution in our Family!

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: But that shou'd not make you neglect your duty to me, your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Pretty Soul; I wou'd thou wert: upon condition that old Bromia were six Foot under ground.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: What! Is all your hot Courtship to me, dwindl'd into a poor unprofitable Wish? You may remember, I did not bid you absolutely despair.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: No; for all things yet may be accommodated, in an amicable manner, betwixt my Master and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: I mean, to the Business, betwixt you and me—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Why, I hope we two never quarrell'd?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Must I remember you of a certain Promise that you made me at our last parting?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Oh, when I went to the Army: that I shou'd still be praising thy Beauty to Judge Gripus, and keep up his Affections to thee.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, I mean the Business betwixt you and me this Morning—: that you promis'd me—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: That I promis'd thee.— I find it now: That strong Dog, my Brother Sosia, has been here before me, and made Love to her. Aside.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: You are considering, whether or no, you should keep your Promise—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: That I shou'd keep my Promise.— The truth on't is, she's anotherghess Morsel than old Bromia. Aside.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And I had rather you should break it, in a manner, and, as it were, and in some Sense.—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: In a manner, and as it were, and in some Sense, thou say'st?— I find, the strong Dog has only tickl'd up her Imagination, and not enjoy'd her: so that with my own Limbs, I may perform the sweetness of his Function with her. Aside. No, sweet Creature, the Promise shall not be broken; but what I have undertaken, I will perform like a Man of Honour. To her.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: Then, you remember the Preliminaries of the Present—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Yes, yes, in gross I do remember, something; but this disturbance of the Family, has somewhat stupify'd my Memory: Some pretty Quelque chose, I warrant thee; some acceptable Toy, of small value.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You may call a Gold Goblet, a Toy: But I put a greater value upon your Presents.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: A Gold Goblet, say'st thou! Yes, now I think on't, it was a kind of a Gold Goblet; as a Gratuity after Consummation.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, no; I had rather make sure of one Bribe before hand, than be promis'd ten Gratuities.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Yes, now I remember, it was, in some Sense, a Gold Goblet, by way of Earnest; and it contain'd—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: One large—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.l: How, one large—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Gallon.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p:
No; that was somewhat too large, in Conscience: It was not a whole Gallon; but it may contain, reasonably speaking, one large— Thimble-full:
But Gallons and Thimble-fulls are so like, that in speaking, I might easily mistake them.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Is it come to this? Out Traytor!

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I had been a Traytor, indeed, to have betray'd thee to the swallowing of a Gallon: but a Thimblefull of Cordial-water, is easily sipt off: and then, this same Goblet, is so very light too, that it will be no Burthen, to carry it about with thee, in thy Pocket.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: O Apostate to thy Love! O perjur'd Villain! Enter Bromia. What, are you here, Bromia! I was telling him his own: I was giving him a Rattle for his Treacheries to you, his Love: You see I can be a Friend, upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay, Chicken, I never doubted of thy Kindness: but, for this Fugitive,— this Rebel,— this Miscreant.—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: A kind Welcome, to an absent Lover, as I have been.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay; and a kind Greeting you gave me, at your Return; when you us'd me so barbarously, this Morning.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: The t'other Sosia has been with her too: and has us'd her barbarously: barbarously, that is to say, uncivilly: and uncivilly; I am afraid that means, too civilly. Aside.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You had best deny you were here this Morning! And by the same Token—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Nay, no more Tokens, for Heaven's sake, dear Phaedra.
Now must I ponder with my self a little, whether it be better for me, to have been here, or not to have been here, this Morning. Aside.

div.stage: Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Phaedra, My Lord's without; and will not enter till he has first spoken with you Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Phaed
sp.p: Oh that I could stay to help worry thee for this Abuse: To him in private. but the best on't is, I leave thee in good hands—— Farewell Thimble.— To him, Bromia. Exit Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No; you did not beat me, and put me into a Swound, and deprive me of the natural use of my Tongue for a long Half-hour: You did not beat me down, with your little Wand: But I shall teach you to use your Rod another time— I shall.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Put her into a Swound, with my little Wand, and so forth: That's more than ever I cou'd do. These are terrible Circumstances that some Sosia or another, has been here: Now, if he has literally beaten her, Grammercy, Brother Sosia; he has but done, what I wou'd have done, if I had durst: But I am afraid it was only a damn'd Love-figure; and that the Wand that lay'd her asleep, might signifie the Peace-maker. Aside.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Now you are snuffling upon a cold Scent, for some pitiful Excuse: I know you: twenty to one, but you will plead a Drunkenness: You are usd to be pot-valiant.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I was pumping, and I thank her, she has invented for me.— Yes; Bromia, I must confess I was exalted: and, possibly, I might scoure upon thee, or perhaps be a little more familiar with thy person, by the way of Kindness, than if I had been sober; but, prithee, inform me what I did; that I may consider what satisfaction I am to make thee.

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: Are you there, at your Dog-tricks! You wou'd be forgetting, wou'd you? like a drunken Bully that affronts over-night, and, when he is call'd to account, the next Morning, remembers nothing of the Quarrel; and asks pardon, to avoid fighting.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: By Bacchus, I was overtaken; but I shou'd be loth that I committed any folly with thee.

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: I am sure, I kept my self awake all night, that I did, in expectation of your coming. Crying.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: But what amends did I make thee, when I came!

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: You know well enough, to my sorrow; but that you play the Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I warrant, I was monstrous kind to thee.—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes, monstrous kind indeed: You never said a truer word: for, when I came to kiss you, you pull'd away your Mouth, and turn'd your Cheek to me.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: How, Good! Here's fine Impudence: He justifies!—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Yes, I do justifie, that I turn'd my Cheek, like a prudent person, that my Breath might not offend thee: for, now I remember, I had eaten Garlick.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay, you remember, and forget, just as it makes for you, or against you: but, to mend the matter, you never spoke one civil word to me: but stood like a stock, without sense or motion.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Yet better. Aside.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: After which, I lovingly invited you to take your place in your Nuptial Bed, as the Laws of Matrimony oblige you: and you inhumanly refus'd me.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Ay, there's the main point of the Business! Art thou morally certain, that I refus'd thee: Look me now in the face, and say I did not commit Matrimony with thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I wonder how thou canst look me in the face, after that refusal!

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Say it once again, that I did not feloniously come to Bed to thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No, thou cold Traytor, thou know'st thou didst not.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Best of all; 'twas discreetly done of me to abstain.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: What do you insult upon me too!

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.l: No, I do not insult upon you;— but—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: But what? How was it discreetly done then? Ha!

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Because it is the receiv'd Opinion of Physicians, that nothing but puling Chitts, and Booby-Fools, are procreated in Drunkenness.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p:
A receiv'd Opinion, Snivel-guts! I'll be judg'd by all the marry'd Women of this Town, if any one of 'em has receiv'd it: The Devil take the Physicians, for medling in our Matters: If a Husband will be rul'd by them, there are five weeks of Abstinence in Dog-days too; for fear a Child that was
got in August, should be born just nine Months after, and be blear-ey'd, like a May-Kitten.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Let the Physicians alone; they are honest Men, whatever the World says of 'em. But, for a certain reason, that I best know, I am glad that Matter ended so fairly and peaceably betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes 'twas very fair and peaceable: to strike a Woman down, and beat her most outrageously.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Is it possible that I drubb'd thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I find your drift: You wou'd fain be provoking me to a new Trial now: but, i'faith, you shall bring me to no more handy-blows: I shall make bold to trust to my Tongue hereafter: You never durst have offer'd to hold up a finger against me, till you went a Trooping.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Then I am a Conqueror: and I laud my own Courage: This Renown I have atchiev'd by Souldiership and Stratagem. Know your Duty, Spouse, henceforward to your supream Commander. Strutting.

div.stage: Enter Jupiter and Phaedra, attended by Musicians and Dancers.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Indeed I wondred at your quick return.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Ev'n so Almighty Love will have it, Phaedra;
And the stern Goddess of sweet-bitter Cares,
Who bows our Necks beneath her brazen Yoke.
I wou'd have mann'd my heart, and held it out;
But, when I thought of what I had possest;
Those joys, that never end, but to begin,
O, I am all on fire to make my peace:
And die, Jove knows, as much as I can die,
Till I am reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I fear't will be in vain.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: 'Tis difficult:
But nothing is impossible to Love:
To Love like mine; for I have prov'd his force,
And my Alcmena too has felt his Dart.
If I submit, there's hope.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: 'Tis possible I may sollicit for you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: But wilt thou promise me to do thy best?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: Nay I promise nothing— unless you begin
To promise first.— Curt'sying.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: I wou'not be ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well; I'll try to bring her to the Window: You shall have a fair shoot at her: if you can bring her down, you are a good Markes-man.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That's all I ask:
And I will so reward thee, Gentle Phaedra.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: What, with Cats-guts and Rosin! This Sol-la; is but a lamentable, empty, sound.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Then there's a sound will please thee better. Throwing her a Purse.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: Ay, there's something of Melody in this sound.
I cou'd dance all day, to the Musick of Chink, Chink. Exit Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Go Sosia round our Thebes,
To Polydas, to Tranio, and to Gripus,
Companions of our War; invite 'em all,
To joyn their Pray'rs to smooth Alcmena's Brow;
And, with a solemn Feast, to crown the day.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.l: Let me embrace you, Sir.— Jupiter pushes him away:
sp.p: Nay, you must give me leave to express my Gratitude; I have not eaten, to say eating, nor drunk, to say drinking, never since our villanous encamping so near the Enemy: 'Tis true, I scap'd the bloody-Flux, because I had so little in my Bowels to come out, and I durst let nothing go, in Conscience, because I had nothing to swallow in the room on't.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You, Bromia, see that all things be prepar'd,
With that Magnificence, as if some God
Were Guest, or Master here.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Or rather, as much, as if twenty Gods were to be Guests, or Masters here.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: That you may eat for to day, and to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Or, rather again, for to day and yesterday; and as many Months backwards, as I am indebted to my own Belly.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Away both of you. Exeunt Sosia and Bromia severally.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Now I have pack'd him hence; thou, other Sosia,
(Who, tho' thou art not present, hear'd my voice,)
Be ready to attend me at my Call;
And to supply his place. Enter Mercury to Jupiter.

div.stage: Alcmena and Phaedra appear above.
Jupiter seeing Alcmena,

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: See, she appears:
This is my Bribe to Phaedra; when I made
This Gold, I made a greater God than Jove,
And gave my own Omnipotence away.

div.stage: Jupiter signs to the Musicians. Song and Dance: after which, Alcmena withdraws, frowning.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: CElia, that I once was blest
Is now the Torment of my Brest;
Since to curse me, you bereave me
Of the Pleasures I possest:
Cruel Creature, to deceive me!
First to love, and then to leave me!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Had you the Bliss refus'd to grant,
Then I had never known the want:
But possessing once the Blessing,
Is the Cause of my Complaint:
Once possessing is but tasting;
'Tis no Bliss that is not lasting.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Celia now is mine no more;
But I am hers; and must adore:
Nor to leave her will endeavour;
Charms, that captiv'd me before,
No unkindness can dissever;
Love that's true, is Love for ever.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: O stay.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: She's gone; and seem'd to frown at parting.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Follow, and thou shalt see her soon appeas'd:
For I, who made her, know her inward state;
No Woman, once well pleas'd, can throughly hate:
I gave 'em Beauty, to subdue the strong:
(A mighty Empire, but it lasts not long:)
I gave 'em Pride to make Mankind their Slave;
But, in exchange, to Men I Flattery gave:
Th' offending Lover, when he lowest lies,
Submits, to conquer; and but kneels, to rise.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: The FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Jupiter following Alcmena; Mercury and Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: O Stay, my dear Alcmena, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: No, I wou'd fly thee, to the ridge of earth,
And leap the Precipice, to scape thy sight.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: For pity—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Leave me, thou ungrateful Man.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I cannot leave you: no; but like a Ghost
Whom your Unkindness murder'd, will I haunt you.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Once more, be gone: I'm odious to my self
For having lov'd thee once.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Hate not the best and fairest of your kind:
Nor can you hate your Lover, tho' you wou'd:
Your Tears, that fall so gently, are but grief:
There may be Anger; but there must be Love.
The Dove, that murmurs at her Mate's neglect,
But counterfeits a coyness, to be courted.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Courtship, from thee, and after such affronts!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Is this that everlasting Love you vow'd,
Last Night, when I was circled in your arms?
Remember what you swore.—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Think what thou wert, and who cou'd swear too much?
Think what thou art, and that unswears it all.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Can you forsake me, for so small a fault?
'Twas but a Jest, perhaps too far pursu'd:
'Twas but at most, a Trial of your Faith,
How you cou'd bear unkindness:
'Twas but to get a reconciling Kiss,
A wanton Stratagem of Love.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: See how he doubles, like a hunted Hare,
A Jest, and then a Trial, and a Bait;
All stuff, and dawbing!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Think me jealous, then:

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: O that I cou'd; for that's a noble Crime;
And which a Lover can, with ease, forgive:
'Tis the high pulse of Passion, in a Fever;
A sickly draught, but shews a burning Thirst:
Thine was a Surfeit, not a Jealousie:
And in that loathing of thy full gorg'd Love,
Thou saw'st the nauseous Object, with disdain.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O think not that: for you are ever new:
Your fruits of Love, are like eternal Spring
In happy Climes, where some are in the bud,
Some green, and ripening some, while others fall.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Ay, now you tell me this,
When rous'd desires, and fresh recruits of force,
Enable languish'd Love to take the field.
But never hope to be receiv'd again:
You wou'd again deny you were receiv'd;
And brand my spotless Fame.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I will not dare to justifie my Crime,
But only point you where to lay the blame:
Impute it to the Husband, not the Lover.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: How vainly wou'd the Sophister divide,
And make the Husband and the Lover, two!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Yes 'tis the Husband is the guilty Wretch:
His Insolence forgot the Sweets of Love,
And, deeming them his due, despis'd the Feast.
Not so the famish'd Lover cou'd forget:
He knew he had been there, and had been blest,
With all that Hope can wish, or Sense can bear:

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Husband, and Lover, both alike I hate.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And I confess I have deserv'd that hate: Kneeling.
Too charming fair, I kneel for your forgiveness:
I beg by those fair eyes,
Which gave me wounds, That time can never cure;
Receive my Sorrows, and restore my Joys.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Unkind, and cruel! I can speak no more.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O give it vent Alcmena, give it vent;
I merit your reproach, I wou'd be curs'd:
Let your Tongue curse me, while your Heart forgives.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Can I forget such Usage!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Can you hate me?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: I'll do my best: for sure I ought to hate you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That Word was only hatch'd upon your Tongue,
It came not from your Heart. But try again,
And if, once more, you can but say, I hate you,
My Sword shall do you justice.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Then, I hate you.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Then you pronounce the Sentence of my Death?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: I hate you, much; but yet I love you more.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: To prove that Love, then say, that you forgive me:
For there remains but this Alternative:
Resolve to pardon, or to punish me.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Alas, what I resolve appears too plain:
In saying that I cannot hate, I pardon.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: But what's a Pardon worth, without a Seal?
Permit it me, in this Transport of my Joy— Kisses her Hand.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Forbear; I am offended with my self, Putting him gently away with her Hand.
That I have shewn this Weakness.— Let me go,
Where I may blush, alone.— Going; and looking back on him.
But come not you:
Lest I shou'd spoil you, with excess of Fondness,
And let you love again.— Exit Alcmena.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Forbidding me to follow, she invites me: Aside.
This is the Mou'd of which I made the Sex:
I gave 'em but one Tongue, to say us nay;
And two kind Eyes, to grant. Be sure that none To Mercury.
Approach, to interrupt our privacy Exit Jupiter after Alcmena.

div.stage: Mercury and Phaedra remain.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Your Lady has made the Challenge of Reconciliation to my Lord: Here's a fair Example for us two, Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No Example at all, Sosia: for my Lady had the Diamonds aforehand, and I have none of the Gold Goblet.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: The Goblet shall be forth coming; if thou wilt give me weight for weight.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Yes, and measure for measure too, Sosia: that is, For a Thimbleful of Gold, a Thimbleful of Love.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What think you now, Phaedra? Here's Pulling out the Goblet in a Case, from under his Cloak. a weighty Argument of Love for you.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Now Jupiter, of his Mercy, let me kiss thee, O thou Taking it in both Hands. dear Metal!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And Venus, of her Mercy, let me kiss thee, dear, dear Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Not so fast, Sosia! there's a damn'd Proverb in your way: Many things happen betwixt the Cup and the Lips, you know.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not cheat me of my Goblet?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Yes; as sure as you wou'd cheat me of my Maiden-head: I am yet, but just even with you, for the last Trick you play'd me. And, besides; this is but a bare Retaining Fee; you must give me another, before the Cause is open'd.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Shall I not come to your Bed side, to Night?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, nor to Morrow-Night, neither: but this shall be my Sweet-heart in your place: 'tis a better Bed-fellow, and will keep me warmer, in cold Weather. Exit Phaedra.

div.stage: Mercury alone.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Now, what's the God of Wit in a Woman's Hand? This very Goblet I stole from Gripus; and he got it out of Bribes too. But this is the common fate of ill gotten Goods, that as they came in by Covetousness, they go out by Whoring.— Oh, here's Amphitryon again, but I'll Enter Amphitryon. manage him above, in the Balcony. Exit Mercury.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Not one of those I look'd for, to be found!
As some Enchantment hid 'em from my sight!
Perhaps, as Sosia says, 'tis Witchcraft all:
Seals may be open'd, Diamonds may be stol'n;
But how I came, in person, yesterday,
And gave that Present to Alcmena's hands,
That which I never gave, nor ever came,
O there's the Rock, on which my Reason splits:
Wou'd that were all! I fear my Honour, too!
I'll try her once again: She may be mad:
A wretched Remedy; but all I have,
To keep me from despair.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: This is no very charitable Action of a God, to From the Balcony, use him ill, who has never offended me: but my Planet Aside. disposes me to Malice: and when we great Persons do but a little Mischief, the World has a good bargain of us.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How now! what means the locking up of my Doors, at this time of day? Knocks.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Softly, Friend, softly: You knock as loud, and as sawcily, as a Lord's Footman, that was sent before him, to warn the Family of his Honour's Visit. Sure you think the Doors have no feeling! What the Devil are you, that rap with such Authority?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Look out, and see: 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You: What You?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: No more, I say, but open.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I'll know to whom first?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I am one that can command the doors open.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Then you had best command 'em, and try whether they will obey You.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dost thou not know me!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Prithee, how shou'd I know thee? Dost thou take me for a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What's this Midsummer-Moon? Is all the World gone a madding? Why Sosia!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That's my Name indeed: Didst thou think I had forgot it!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dost thou see me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, dost thou pretend to go invisible? If thou hast any business here, dispatch it quickly; I have no leasure to throw away upon such pratling Companions.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Thy Companion, Slave? How dar'st thou use this insolent Language to thy Master!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How! Thou my Master? By what Title? I never had any other Master, but Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Well: and for whom dost thou take me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: For some Rogue or other; but what Rogue I know not.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dost thou not know me for Amphitryon, Slave!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How shou'd I know thee, when I see thou dost not know thy self! thou Amphitryon? In what Tavern hast thou been? And how many Bottles did thy business, to metamorphose thee into my Lord?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I will so drub thee, for this insolence.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How now, Impudence! are you threatning your Betters! I shou'd bring you to condign punishment, but that I have a great respect for the good Wine, though I find it in a Fool's Noddle.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What, none to let me in? Why Phaedra! Bromia!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Peace Fellow; if my Wife hears thee, we are both undone. At a word, Phaedra and Bromia are very busie; one in making a Cawdle for my Lady; and the other in heating Napkins, to rub down my Lord, when he rises from Bed.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Amazement seizes me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: At what art thou amaz'd? My Master and my Lady had a falling out, and are retir'd, without Seconds, to decide the Quarrel. If thou wert not a meddlesome Fool, thou woud'st not be thrusting thy Nose into other Peoples Matters. Get thee about thy business, if thou hast any; for I'll hear no more of thee. Exit Mercury from above.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Brav'd by my Slave, dishonour'd by my Wife,
To what a desp'rate plunge am I reduc'd,
If this be true the Villain says? But why
That feeble, If! It must be true; She owns it.
Now, whether to conceal, or blaze th' Affront?
One way, I spread my infamy abroad;
And, t'other, hide a burning coal, within;
That preys upon my Vitals: I can fix
On nothing, but on Vengeance.

div.stage: Enter to him Sosia, Polydas, Gripus, Tranio.

sp.speaker: Gripus.
sp.p: Yonder he is; walking hastily to and fro, before his door; like a Citizen, clapping his Sides before his Shop, in a frosty Morning: 'tis to catch a Stomach, I believe.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I begin to be affraid, that he has more stomach to my Sides, and Shoulders, than to his own Victuals. How he shakes his head! and stamps, and what strides he fetches! He's in one of his damn'd Moods again; I don't like the Looks of him.

sp.speaker: Amph
sp.p: Oh, my mannerly, fair-spoken, obedient Slave, are you there! I can reach you now, without climbing: Now we shall try who's drunk, and who's sober.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Why this is as it shou'd be: I was somewhat suspicious that you were in a pestilent humour; Yes, we will have a crash at the Bottle, when your Lordship pleases: I have summo'nd 'em, you see; and they are notable Topers; especially Judge Gripus.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Yes, faith; I never refuse my Glass, in a good Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Why, thou insolent Villain; I'll teach a Slave how to use his Master hus. To Sosia.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Here's a fine business towards! I am sure I ran as fast as ever my legs cou'd carry me, to call 'em: nay you may trust my diligence, in all affairs belonging to the belly.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: He has been very faithfull to his Commission, I'll bear him witness.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How can you be witness, where you were not present? the Balcony! Sirrah, the Balcony!

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Why, to my best remembrance, you never invited the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What nonsence dost thou plead for an Excuse, of thy foul language, and thy base replies!

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: You fright a man out of his senses, first; and blame him, afterwards, for talking nonsence:— but 'tis better for me to talk nonsence, than for some to do nonsence: I will say that, what e'er comes on't. Pray Sir, let all things be done decently: what, I hope, when a man is to be hang'd, he is not truss'd upon the Gallows, like a dumb Dog, without telling him wherefore.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: By your pardon, Gentlemen: I have no longer patience to forbear him.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Justice, justice, my Lord Gripus: as you are a true Magistrate, protect me. Here's a process of Beating going forward, without sentence given.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: My Lord Amphitryon, this must not be: Let me first understand the demerits of the Criminal.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Hold you to that point, I beseech your Honour, as you commiserate the Case of a poor, innocent Malefactour.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: To shut the door against me, in my very face, to deny me entrance, to brave me from the Balcony, to laugh at me, to threaten me: what proofs of Innocence call you these? but if I punish not this Insolence— Is going to beat him and is held by Polydas and Tranio. I beg you let me go—

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I charge you in the King's name, hold him fast; for you see he's bloodily dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now, what hast thou to say for thy self, Sosia?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I say, in the first place, be sure you hold him, Gentlemen; for I shall never plead worth one farthing, while I am bodily affraid.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Speak boldly; I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Then, if I may speak boldly, under my Lord's favour, I do not say he lyes neither: no, I am too well bred for that: but his Lordship fibbs most abominably.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Do you hear his Impudence? yet will you let me go?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: No Impudence at all, my Lord: for how cou'd I, naturally speaking, be in the Balcony, and affronting you; when at the same time I was in every Street of Thebes, inviting these Gentlemen to Dinner?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hold a little: how long since was it that he spoke to you, from the said Balcony?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Just now; not a Minute before he brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Now speak my Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I can answer for him, for this last half hour.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Now judge equitably, Gentlemen; whether I was not a civil well-bred person, to tell my Lord he fibbs onely.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Who gave you that order, to invite 'em?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: He that best might; your self: by the same token, you bid old Bromia provide and 'twere for a God: and I put in for a brace, or a lease; no, now I think on't, it was for ten couple of Gods, to make sure of plenty.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: When did I give thee this pretended Commission?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Why you gave me this pretended Commission, when you were just ready to give my Lady the Fiddles and a Dance; in order, as I suppose, to your second bedding.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Where, in what place, did I give this order?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Here, in this place; in the presence of this very door, and of that Balcony: and if they cou'd speak, they wou'd both justifie it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Heaven! these accidents are so surprizing, that the more I think of 'em, the more I am lost in my imagination.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, he has told us some passages, as he came along, that seem to surpass the power of Nature

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: What think you now, my Lord, of a certain twin Brother of mine, call'd Sosia? 'tis a sly Youth: pray Heaven you have not just such another Relation, within doors, call'd Amphitryon. It may be it was he, that put upon me, in your likeness: and perhaps he may have put something upon your Lordship too, that may weigh heavy upon the forehead.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: to those who hold him. Let me go:— Sosia may be innocent, and I will not hurt him:— Open the door; I'll resolve my doubts immediately.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: The door is peremptory, that it will not be open'd without Keys: and my Brother, on the inside, is in possession; and will not part with 'em.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Then 'tis manifest that I am affronted; break open the door there.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Stir not a man of you, to his assistance.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Dost thou take part with my Adultress too, because she is thy Niece?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I take part with nothing, but the Law; and, to break the doors open, is to break the Law.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Do thou command 'em, then.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I command nothing without my Warrant; and my Clerk is not here to take his Fees for drawing it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: (aside) The Devil take all Justice-brokers:— I curse him too when I have been hunting him all over the Town, to be my Witness!— But I'll bring Souldiers to force open the doors, by my own Commission. Exit. Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Pox o' these forms of Law, to defeat a man of a Dinner, when he's sharp set 'tis against the priviledge of a free-born Stomack; and is no less than subversion of Fundamentals. Jupiter above in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: Oh, my Friends, I am sorry I have made you wait so long: you are welcome; and the door shall be open'd to you, immediately. Exit. Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Was not that Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Why, who shou'd it be else?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: In all appearance it was he: but how got he thither?

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: In such a trice too!

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: And after he had just left us?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: And so much alter'd, for the better, in his humour?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Here's such a company of foolish questions, when a man's a hungry: You had best stay dinner till he has prov'd himself to be Amphitryon in form of Law: But I'll make short work of that business: for I'll take mine Oath 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I shou'd be glad it were.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: How glad it were? with your damn'd Interrogatories, when you ought to be thankfull, that so it is.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: (aside) That I may see my Mistress Phaedra, and present her with my great gold Gobblet.

sp.speaker: Sosia,
sp.p: If this be not the true Amphitryon, I wish I may be kept without doors, fasting, and biting my own Fingers, for want of Victuals; and that's a dreadfull Imprecation! I am for the inviting, and eating, and treating Amphitryon: I am sure 'tis he that is my lawfully begotten Lord: and if you had an Ounce of true Justice in you, you ought to have laid hold on t'other Amphitryon, and committed him for a Rogue, and an Impostour, and a Vagabond.

div.stage: The Door is open'd: Mercury from within.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Enter quickly, Masters: The Passage on the right-hand leads to the Gallery, where my Lord expects you:— for I am call'd another way.

div.stage: Gripus, Tranio, and Polydas go into the House.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I shou'd know that Voice, by a secret Instinct: 'tis a Tongue of my Family; and belongs to my Brother Sosia: it must be so; for it carries a cudgelling kind of sound in it.— But put the worst: let me weigh this matter wisely: Here's a beating, and a belly-full: against no beating, and no belly-full. The beating is bad; but the dinner is good: now, not to be beaten, is but negatively good; but, not to fill my belly, is positively bad.— Upon the whole matter, my final resolution is, to take the good and the bad as they come together. Is entring: Mercury meets him at the Door.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Whither now, you kitchen-skumm? From whence this Impudence, to enter here without permission?

sp.speaker: Sosia,
sp.p: Most Illustrious Sir: my Ticket is my hunger: shew the full Bowe's of your Compassion, to the empty bowels of my famine.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Were you not charg'd to return no more? I'll cut you into quarters, and hang you upon the Shambles.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: You'll get but little credit by me: Alas, Sir, I am but mere Carrion! Brave Sosia, compassionate Coward Sosia: and beat not thy self, in beating me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Who gave you that privilege, Sirrah, to assume my Name? have you not been sufficiently warn'd of it? and receiv'd part of punishment already?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: May it please you, Sir, the Name is big enough for both of us: and we may use it in common, like a Strumpet: witness heaven, that I wou'd have obey'd you, and quitted my Title to the name; but, where ever I come, the malicious world will call me Sosia, in spight of me: I am sensible there are two Amphitryons; and why may not there be two Sosia's? Let those two cut one anothers throats at their own pleasure: but you and I will be wiser, by my consent, and hold good Intelligence together.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, no: Two Sosia's wou'd but make two fools.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Then let me be the fool; and be you the prudent person: and chuse for your self some wiser name: or you shall be the Elder Brother; and I'll be content to be the Younger; though I lose my Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I tell thee, I am the onely Son of our Family.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Then let me be your Bastard Brother, and the Son of a Whore; I hope that's but reasonable.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, Thou shalt not disgrace my Father: For there are few Bastards now-a days worth owning.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Ah! Poor Sosia! What will become of thee?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yet again profanely using my proper name?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I did not mean my self: I was thinking of another Sosia, a poor fellow, that was once of my acquaintance, unfortunately banish'd out of doors, when dinner was just coming upon the Table.

div.stage: Enter Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Sosia, you and I must— Bless me! What have we here, a Couple of you, or do I see double?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I wou'd fain bring it about, that I might make one of 'em: But he's unreasonable and will needs incorporate me, and swallow me whole into himself. If he wou'd be content to be but one and a half, 'twou'd never grieve me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis a perverse Rascal: I kick him, and cudgel him to no purpose: for still he's obstinate to stick to me: and I can never beat him out of my resemblance.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Which of you two is Sosia? For t'other must be the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: You had best ask him that has play'd the Devil with my back and sides.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You had best ask him who gave you the gold Gobblet?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, that's already given: but he shall be my Sosia, that will give me such another.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I find you have been Interloping, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: No, indeed, Sir; I onely promised her a gold Thimble: which was as much as comes to my proportion of being Sosia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: This is no Sosia for my money: beat him away t'other Sosia: he grows insufferable.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: (aside) Wou'd I were valiant, that I might beat him away; and succeed him at the dinner; for a pragmatical Son of a Whore, as he is—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What's that you are muttering betwixt your Teeth, of a Son of a Whore, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I am sure I meant you no offence: for, if I am not Sosia, I am the Son of a Whore, for ought I know: and, if you are Sosia, you may be the Son of a Whore for ought you know.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What ever I am, I will be Sosia, as long as I please: and whenever you visit me, you shall be sure of the civility of the Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: If you will promise to beat me into the house, you may begin when you please with me: but, to be beaten out of the house, at dinner time, flesh and bloud can never bear it.

div.stage: Mercury beats him about, and Sosia is still making towards the door: but Mercury gets betwixt; and at length drives him off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: In the name of wonder, what are you, that are Sosia, and are not Sosia?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: If thou would'st know more of me, my person is freely at thy disposing.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then I dispose of it to you again: for 'tis so ugly, 'tis not for my use.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I can be ugly or handsome, as I please: go to bed old, and rise young. I have so many Sutes of persons by me, that I can shift 'em when I will.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You are a fool then, to put on your worst Cloaths, when you come a wooing.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Go to: Ask no more questions; I am for thy turn; for I know thy heart: and see all thou hast about thee.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then you can see my back-side too; there's a bargain for you.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In thy right pocket:— let me see:— three Love Letters from Judge Gripus, written to the bottom, on three sides; full of sustian passion, and hearty non-sence: as also in the same Pocket, a Letter of thine intended to him; consisting of nine lines and a half: scrawl'd and false spell'd, to show thou art a Woman; and full of fraudulence, and equivocations, and shoeing-horns of Love to him; to promise much, and mean nothing; to show, over and above, that thou art a mere Woman.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Is the Devil in you, to see all this? Now, for Heavens sake, do not look into t'other Pocket.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Nay, there's nothing there, but a little godly Prayer-book, and— a bawdy Lampoon, and—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Look no farther, I beseech you.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: And a Silver Spoon—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: (Shreeking.)— Ah!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Which you purloin'd last Night from Bromia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Keep my Counsel, or I am undone for ever. Holding up her hands to him.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No: I'll mortifie thee, now I have a handle to thy Iniquity, if thou wilt not love me.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well, if you'll promise me to be secret, I will love you: because indeed I dare doe no other.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis a good Girl; I will be secret; and further, I will be assisting to thee in thy filching: for thou and I were born under the same Planet.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And we shall come to the same end too, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No; no; since thou hast wit enough already to couzin a Judge, thou need'st never fear hanging.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And will you make your self a younger man; and be handsome too: and rich? for you that know hearts, must needs know, that I shall never be constant to such an ugly old Sosia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thou shalt know more of that another time: in the mean while, here's a cast of my Office for thee.

div.stage: He stamps upon the ground: some Dancers come from underground: and others from the sides of the Stage: A Song, and a fantastick Dance.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FAir Iris I love, and hourly I dye,
But not for a Lip, nor a languishing Eye:
She's fickle and false, and there we agree;
For I am as false, and as fickle as she:
We neither believe what either can say;
And, neither believing, we neither betray.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: 'Tis civil to swear, and say things of course;
We mean not the taking for better for worse.
When present, we love; when absent, agree:
I think not of Iris, nor Iris of me:
The Legend of Love no Couple can find
So easie to part, or so equally join'd.

div.stage: After, the Dance.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: This Power of yours makes me suspect you for little better than a God; but if you are one, for more certainty, tell me what I am just now thinking.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, thou art thinking, let me see; for thou art a Woman, and your minds are so variable, that it's very hard even for a God to know them. But, to satisfie thee, thou art wishing, now, for the same Power I have exercis'd; that thou mightest stamp, like me; and have more Singers come up for another Song.

sp.speaker: Phaedra,
sp.p: Gad, I think the Devil's in you. Then I do stamp in some body's Name, but I know not whose; (stamps.) Come up, Gentle-folks, from below; and sing me a Pastoral Dialogue, where the Woman may have the better of the Man; as we always have in Love matters. New Singers come up and sing a Song.

div.head: A Pastoral Dialogue betwixt Thyrsis and Iris.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Thyrsis. FAir Iris and her Swain
Were in a shady Bow'r;
Where Thyrsis long in vain
Had sought the Shepherd's hour:
At length his Hand advancing upon her snowy Breast;
He said, O kiss me longer,
And longer yet and longer,
If you will make me Blest.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Iris. An easie yielding Maid,
By trusting is undone;
Our Sex is oft betray'd,
By granting Love too soon.
If you desire to gain me, your Suff'rings to redress;
Prepare to love me longer,
And longer yet, and longer,
Before you shall possess.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Thyrsis. The little Care you show,
Of all my Sorrows past;
Makes Death appear too slow,
And Life too long to last.
Fair Iris kiss me kindly, in pity of my Fate;
And kindly still, and kindly,
Before it be too late.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Iris. You fondly Court your Bliss,
And no Advances make;
'Tis not for Maids to kiss,
But 'tis for Men to take.
So you may Kiss me kindly, and I will not rebell;
And kindly still, and kindly,
But Kiss me not and tell.

lg.head: V. A RONDEAU.
lg.l: Chorus. Thus at the height we love and live,
And fear not to be poor:
We give, and give, and give, and give,
Till we can give no more:
But what to day will take away,
To morrow will restore.
Thus at the heighth we love and live,
And fear not to be poor.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Adieu, I leave you to pay the Musick: Hope well Mr. Planett; there's a better Heav'n in store for you: I say no more, but you can guess.

div.stage: Mercury, alone.

q.l: Such Bargain-loves, as I with Phaedra treat,
Are all the Leagues and Friendships of the Great:
All seek their Ends; and each wou'd other cheat.
They onely seem to hate, and seem to love;
But Int'rest is the point on which they move.
Their Friends are Foes; and Foes are Friends agen;
And, in their turns, are Knaves, and Honest men.
Our Iron Age is grown an Age of Gold:
'Tis who bids most; for all Men wou'd be sold. Exit Mercury.

div.head: ACT. V. Gripus, Phaedra.
div.stage: Gripus has the Gobblet in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: YOU will not be so base to take it from me?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Tis my proper Chattel: and I'll seize my own, in whatever hands I find it.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You know I onely show'd it you to provoke your generosity, that you might out-bid your Rival with a better Present.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: My Rival is a Thief: and I'll indite you for a Receiver of Stoln Goods.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou Hide-bound Lover!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou very mercenary Mistress!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou most mercenary Magistrate!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou Seller of thy self!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou Seller of other People: thou Weather-cock of Government: that when the Wind blows for the Subject, point'st to Priviledge; and when it changes for the Soveraign, veers to Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Will you compound, and take it as my Present?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No: but I'll send thy Rival to force it from thee.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: When a Thief is Rival to his Judge, the Hangman will soon decide the difference. Exit. Phaedra.

div.stage: Enter Mercury, with two Swords.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Bowing. Save your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: From an Impertinent Coxcomb: I am out of humour, and am in hast: leave me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis my duty to attend on your Lordship, and to ease you of that undecent Burden.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Gold was never any Burden, to one of my Profession.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: By your Lordship's permission, Phaedra has sent me to take it from you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What, by Violence?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: still Bowing. No; but by your Honour's permission, I am to restore it to her, and perswade your Lordship, to renounce your Pretensions to her.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tell her flatly, I will neither do one, nor t'other.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: O my good Lord, I dare pass my word for your free consent to both.— Will your Honour be pleas'd to take your choice of one of these?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why these are Swords: what have I to do with them?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Onely to take your choice of one of them; which your Lordship pleases; and leave the other to your most Obedient Servant.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What, one of these ungodly Weapons? take notice, I'll lay you by the heels, Sirrah: this has the appearance of an unlawfull bloody challenge.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You Magistrates are pleas'd to call it so, my Lord; but with us Sword-men, 'tis an honourable Invitation to the cutting of one anothers Throats.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be answer'd; I have no Throat to cut. The Law shall decide our Controversie.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: By your permission, my Lord; it must be dispatch'd, this way.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'll see thee hang'd before I give thee any such permission, to dispatch me into another World.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: At the least, my Lord, you have no occasion to complain of my want of respect to you: you will neither restore the Gobblet, nor renounce Phaedra: I offer you the Combat; you refuse it: all this is done in the forms of honour: it follows, that I am to affront, cudgel you, or kick you, at my own arbitrement; and I suppose, you are too honourable not to approve of my proceeding.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Here's a new sort of Process, that was never heard of in any of our Courts.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: This, my good Lord, is Law in Short-hand, without your long Preambles, and tedious Repetitions, that signifie nothing, but to squeeze the Subject: therefore, with your Lordship's favour, I begin. Phillips him under the Chin.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What's this for?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: To give you an occasion of returning me a box o'th' Ear: that so, all things may proceed methodically.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I put in no answer, but suffer a Non-suit.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, my Lord; for the Costs and Charges are to be paid: will you please to restore the Cup?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I have told thee, no

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Then from your Chin, I must ascend to your Lordship's Ears.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh, oh. Oh, oh.— Wilt thou never leave lugging me by the Ears?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Not till your Lordship will be pleas'd to hear reason. Pulling again.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Take the Cup; and the Devil give thee joy on't.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: still holding him. And your Lordship will farther be graciously pleas'd, to release all claims, titles, and actions whatsoever to Phaedra: You must give me leave to add one small memento, for that too. Pulling him again.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I renounce her, I release her.

div.stage: Enter Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: to her. Phaedra; My Lord has been pleas'd to be very gracious; without pushing matters to extremity.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I over-heard it all: But give me Livery and Seisin of the Gobblet, in the first place.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: There's an Act of Oblivion shou'd be pass'd too.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Let him begin to remember quarrels, when he dares; now I have him under my Girdle, I'll cap Verses with him to the end of the Chapter.

div.stage: Enter Amphitryon and Guards.

sp.speaker: Amph
sp.p: (to Gripus.) At the last I have got possession without your Lordship's Warrant; Phaedra, tell Alcmena I am here.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I'll carry no such lying Message: you are not here, and you cannot be here: for, to my knowledge, you are above with my Lady, in the Chamber!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: All of a piece, and all Witchcraft! Answer me precisely; do'st thou not know me for Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Answer me first: did you give me a Diamond, and a Purse of Gold?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Thou know'st I did not.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then, by the same token, I know you are not the true Amphitryon: if you are he, I am sure I left you in bed with your own Wife: now you had best stretch out a leg; and feel about for a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I'll undo this Enchantment with my Sword; and kill the Sorcerer: Come up, Gentlemen, and follow me. [To the Guards.]

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I'll save you the labour; and call him down to Confront you; if you dare attend him. Exit. Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: (aside) Now the Spell is ended, and Jupiter can enchant no more; or else Amphitryon had not enter'd so easily. [Gripus is stealing off.]— Whither now, Gripus? I have business for you: if you offer to stir, you know what follows.

div.stage: Enter Jupiter, follow'd by Tranio and Polydas.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Who dares to play the Master in my House?
What noise is this, that calls me from above,
Invades my soft recess, and privacy,
And, like a Tyde, breaks in upon my Love?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Heav'ns, what's this I see?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: What Prodigy!

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: How, two Amphitryons!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: I have beheld th' appearance of two Suns;
But still the false, was dimmer than the true;
Here, both shine out alike.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: This is a sight, that like the Gorgon's head,
Runs through my limbs, and stiffens me to Stone.
I need no more inquire into my fate:
For what I see, resolves my doubts too plain.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Two drops of water, cannot be more like.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: They are two very same's.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: (aside) Our Jupiter is a great Comedian; he counterfeits most admirably: sure his Priests have coppy'd their Hypocrisie from their Master.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Now, I am gather'd back into my self,
My Heart beats high, and pushes out the Blood. [Drawing his Sword]
To give me just revenge on this Impostour. [to the Guards.]
If you are brave, assist me— not one stirs:
What are all brib'd to take th' Enchanters part?
'Tis true, the work is mine; and thus.—
sp.stage: [Going to rush upon Jupiter; and is held by Tranio and Polydas.]

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: It must not be.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Give him his way: I dare the Madman's worst:
But still take notice, that it looks not like
The true Amphitryon, to fly out, at first
To brutal force: it shows he doubts his Cause,
Who dares not trust his reason to defend it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Thou base Usurper of my Name, and Bed;
struggling No less than thy Hearts-blood can wash away
Th' affronts I have sustain'd.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.l: We must not suffer
So strange a Duel as Amphitryon
To fight against himself.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: Nor think we wrong you, when we hold your hands:
We know our duty to our General:
We know the tyes of Friendship to our Friend:
But who that Friend, or who that Gen'ral is,
Without more certain proofs betwixt you two,
Is hard to be distinguish'd, by our reason:
Impossible by sight.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I know it; and have satisfy'd my self:
I am the true Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: See again.
He shuns the certain proofs; and dares not stand
Impartial Judgment, and award of right.
But since Alcmena's honour is concern'd,
Whom, more than Heav'n, and all the World, I love;
This I propose, as equal to us both.
Franio, and Polydas, be you Assistants,
The Guards be ready to secure th' Impostour,
When once so prov'd, for publick punishment;
And Gripus, be thou Umpire of the Cause.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I am content: let him proceed to Examination.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: (aside to Mercury) On whose side woud you please that I shou'd give the Sentence?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
(aside to him) Follow thy Conscience for once; but not to make a Custom of it neither; nor to leave an evil precedent of Uprightness to future
Judges. (Aside) 'Tis a good thing to have a Magistrate under Correction: Your old fornicating Judge, dare never give Sentence against him that knows his haunts.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Your Lordship knows I was Master of Amphitryon's Ship; and desire to know of him, what pass'd in private betwixt us two, at his Landing, when he was just ready to engage the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Let the true Amphitryon answer first.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Peace both of you:— 'Tis a plain Case they are both true; for they both speak together: but for more certainty, let the false Amphitryon speak first.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Now they are both silent—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Then it's as plain on t'other side, that they are both false Amphitryons.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Which Amphitryon shall speak first?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Let the Cholerick Amphitryon speak; and let the peaceable hold his peace.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: to Polydas. You may remember that I whisper'd you, not to part from the Stern, one single Moment.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: You did so.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No more words then; I proceed to Sentence.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: 'Twas I that whisper'd him; and he may remember I gave him this reason for it; That if our Men were beaten, I might secure my own retreat.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: You did so.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now again he's as true as t'other.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.p: You know I was Pay-master: What directions did you give me the night before the Battle?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: To which of the You's art thou speaking?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: (aside) It shou'd be a double U: but they have no such letter in their Tongue.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I order'd you to take particular care of the great Bag.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why this is demonstration.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: The Bag that I recommended to you, was of Tygers skin; and mark'd Beta.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: In sadness I think they are both Jugglers: Here's nothing, and heres nothing: and then hiccius doccius, and they are both here again.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: You peaceable Amphitryon, what Money was there in that Bag?

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: The summ in gross, amounted just to fifty Attick Talents.

sp.speaker: Tran
sp.p: To a farthing?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Paugh: obvious, obvious.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Two thousand pieces of Gold were ty'd up in a Handkerchief by themselves.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I remember it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Then 'tis dubious again.

sp.speaker: Jupit
sp.p: But the rest was not all Silver; for there were just four thousand Brass half-pence.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Being but Brass, the proof is inconsiderable: if they had been Silver, it had gone on your side.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: to Jupit. Death and Hell, you will not perswade me, that I did not kill Pterelas?

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: Nor you me, that I did not enjoy Alcmena?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: That last was poyson to me.— (Aside.)
Yet there's one proof thou canst not counterfeit:
In killing Pterelas, I had a Wound
Full in the brawny part of my right Arme:
Where still the Scar remains: now blush, Impostour;
For this thou canst not show.

div.stage: Bares his Arme; and shows the Scar, which they all look on.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: This is the true Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: May your Lordship please.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, it does not please me: hold your tongue, I charge you; for the Case is manifest.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: By your favour then, this shall speak for me. Bares his Arme; and shows it.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: 'Tis just in the same Muscle.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Of the same length and breadth; and the Scar of the same blewish colour.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: to Jupit. Did not I charge you not to speak? 'twas plain enough before: and now you have puzzled it again.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Good Gods, how can this be!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: For certain there was but one Pterelas; and he must have been in the Plot against himself too: for he was kill'd first by one of them; and then rise again out of respect to t'other Amphitryon, to be kill'd twice over.

div.stage: Enter Alcmena, Phaedra, and Bromia.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: turning to Phaed. and Brom. No more of this; it sounds impossible
That two shou'd be so like, no difference sound.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You'll find it true.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Then where's Alcmena's honour and her fame?
Farewell my needless fear; it cannot be:
This is a Case too nice for vulgar sight:
But let me come; my Heart will guide my Eyes
To point, and tremble to its proper choice.
There neither was, nor is, but one Amphitryon;
And I am onely his.— Goes to take him by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: pushing her away from him. Away, Adultress!

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: My gentle Love: my Treasure and my Joy;
Follow no more, that false and foolish Fire,
That wou'd mislead thy Fame to sure destruction!
Look on thy better Husband, and thy friend,
Who will not leave thee lyable to scorn,
But vindicate thy honour from that Wretch
Who wou'd by base aspersions blot thy vertue.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: going to him, who embraces her. I was indeed mistaken; thou art he!
Thy Words, thy Thoughts, thy Soul is all Amphitryon.
Th' Impostour has thy Features, not thy Mind;
The Face might have deceiv'd me in my choice;
Thy kindness is a Guide that cannot err.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: What in my presence to prefer the Villain!
O execrable cheat! I break the truce;
And will no more attend your vain decisions;
To this— and to the Gods I'll trust my Cause.

div.stage: Is rushing upon Jupiter, and is held again.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Poor Man; how I contemn those idle threats!
Were I dispos'd, thou might'st as safely meet
The Thunder lanch'd from the red arme of Jove:)
(Nor Jove need blush to be Alcmena's Champion.)
But in the face of Thebes, she shall be clear'd:
And what I am, and what thou art, be known.
Attend, and I will bring convincing proof.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Thou wou'dst elude my Justice, and escape;
But I will follow thee, through Earth, and Seas;
Nor Hell shall hide thee, from my just revenge.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: I'll spare thy pains: it shall be quickly seen,
Betwixt us two, who seeks, and who avoids.—
Come in my Friends: and thou who seem'st Amphitryon;
That all who are in doubt, may know the true.

div.stage: Jupiter re-enters the House: with him Amphitryon, Alcmena, Polydas, Tranio, and Guards.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: to Grip. and Brom. who are following. Thou Gripus, and you Bromia; stay with Phaedra:
Let their affairs alone, and mind we ours:
Amphitryon's Rival shall appear a God:
But know before-hand, I am Mercury;
Who want not Heav'n, while Phaedra is on Earth.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: But, and't please your Lordship, is my fellow Phaedra to be exalted into the Heav'ns, and made a Star?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: When that comes to pass, if you look up a-nights, I shall remember old kindness, and vouchsafe to twinkle on you.

div.stage: Enter Sosia, peeping about him: and seeing Mercury, is starting back.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Here he is again; and there's no passing by him into the House, unless I were a Spright, to glide in through the Key-hole.— I am to be a Vagabond I find.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Sosia, come back.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: No I thank you; you may whistle me long enough; a beaten Dog has always the wit to avoid his Master.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I permit thee to be Sosia again.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: 'Tis an unfortunate Name, and I abandon it: he that has an itch to be beaten, let him take it up for Sosia;— What have I said now! I mean for me; for I neither am nor will be Sosia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But thou may'st be so in safety: for I have acknowledg'd my self to be God Mercury.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: You may be a God, for ought I know; but the Devil take me if ever I Worship you; for an unmercifull Deity, as you are.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You ought to take it for an honour to be drubb'd by the hand of a Divinity.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I am your most humble Servant, good Mr. God; but by the faith of a Mortal, I cou'd well have spar'd the honour that you did me. But how shall I be sure that you will never assume my shape again?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Because I am weary of wearing so villanous an outside.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Well, well; as villanous as it is, here's old Bromia will be contented with it.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes, now I am sure that I may chastise you safely: and that there's no God, lurking under your appearance.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: Ay; but you had best take heed how you attempt it: for as Mercury has turn'd himself into me, so I may take the toy into my head, to turn my self into Mercury, that I may swinge you off, condignly.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In the mean time, be all my Witnesses, that I take Phaedra for my Wife of the left hand; that is, in the nature of a lawfull Concubine.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You shall pardon me for believing you, for all you are a God: for you have a terrible ill name below: and I am affraid you'll get a Footman, instead of a Priest, to Marry us.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But here's Gripus shall draw up Articles betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: But he's damnably u'sd to false Conveyancing:— Well be it so: for my Counsel shall over-look 'em before I Sign: Come on, Gripus; that I may have him under black and white Here Gripus gets ready Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: With all my heart; that I may have thee under black and white hereafter.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: to Gripus. Begin, begin; Heads of Articles to be made, &c. betwixt Mercury, God of Thieves—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And Phaedra, Queen of Gypsies.— Imprimis, I promise to buy and settle upon her an Estate, containing Nine thousand Acres of Land, in any part of Boetia, to her own liking.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Provided always, that no part of the said Nine thousand Acres shall be upon, or adjoyning to Mount Parnassus: for I will not be fobb'd off with a Poetical Estate.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Memorandum, that she be always constant to me; and admit no other Lover.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Memorandum, unless it be a Lover that offers more: and that the Constancy shall not exceed the Settlement.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Item, that she shall keep no Male Servants in her house: Item, no Rival Lap Dog for a Bedfellow: Item, that she shall never pray to any of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: What, wou'd you have me an Atheist?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No Devotion to any He-Deity, good Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Here's no provision made for Children yet.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Bromia: I bargain that my Eldest Son shall be a Hero, and my Eldest Daughter a King's Mistress

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That is to say, a Blockhead, and a Harlot, Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: That's true; but who dares call 'em so? Then for the Younger Children:— but now I think on't, we'll have no more, but Mass and Miss; for the rest wou'd be but chargeable, and a burden to the Nation.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yes, yes; the Second shall be a False Prophet: he shall have Wit enough to set up a New Religion: and too much Wit to dye a Martyr for it.

sp.speaker: Phaed
sp.p: O what had I forgot? there's Pin-money, and Ali-money, and Seperate maintenance, and a thousand things more to be consider'd; that are all to be tack'd to this Act of Settlement.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I am a fool, I must confess; but yet I can see as far into a Mill-stone as the best of you: I have observ'd that you Women-Wits are commonly so quick upon the scent, that you often over-run it: Now I wou'd ask of Madam Phaedra, that in case Mr. Heaven there, shou'd be pleas'd to break these Articles, in what Court of Judicature she intends to sue him?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: The fool has hit upon't:— Gods, and great Men, are never to be sued; for they can always plead priviledge of Peerage: and therefore for once, Mounsieur, I'll take your word; for as long as you love me you'll be sure to keep it: and in the mean time I shall be gaining experience how to manage some rich Cully; for no Woman ever made her Fortune by a Wit..

div.stage: It Thunders; and the Company within doors: Amphitryon, Alcmena, Polydas, and Tranio, all come running out, and joyn with the rest, who were on the Theatre before.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Sure 'tis some God: he vanish'd from our sight,
And told, us we shou'd see him soon return.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I know not what to hope, nor what to fear.
A simple Errour, is a real Crime;
And unconsenting Innocence is lost.

div.stage: A second Peal of Thunder. After which, Jupiter appears in a Machine.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Look up, Amphitryon, and behold above,
Th' Impostour God, the Rival of thy Love:
In thy own shape, see Jupiter appear,
And let that sight, secure thy jealous fear.
Disgrace, and Infamy, are turn'd to boast:
No Fame, in Jove's Concurrence can be lost:
What he enjoys, he sanctifies from Vice;
And by partaking, stamps into a price.
'Tis I, who ought to murmur at my Fate;
Forc'd by my Love, my Godhead to translate;
When on no other terms I cou'd possess,
But by thy form, thy features, and thy dress;
To thee were giv'n, the Blessings that I sought,
Which else, not all the bribes of Heav'n had bought.
Then take into thy Armes thy envy'd Love;
And, in his own despight, triumph o'er Jove.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: (aside) Amphitryon and Alcmena, both stand mute, and know not how to take it.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: (aside) Our Soveraign Lord Jupiter is a sly Companion; he knows how to gild a bitter Pill.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: From this auspicious Night, shall rise an Heir,
Great, like his Sire, and like his Mother, fair:
Wrongs to redress, and Tyrants to disseize;
Born for a World, that wants a Hercules.
Monsters, and Monster-men he shall ingage,
And toil, and struggle, through an Impious Age
Peace to his Labours, shall at length succeed;
And murm'ring Men, unwilling to be freed,
Shall be compell'd to Happiness, by need.

div.stage: Jupiter is carry'd back to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We all Congratulate Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Keep your Congratulations to your selves, Gentlemen: 'Tis a nice point, let me tell you that; and the less that is said of it, the better. Upon the whole matter, if Amphitryon takes the favour of Jupiter in patience, as from a God, he's a good Heathen.

sp.speaker: Sosia.
sp.p: I must take a little extraordinary pains to night, that my Spouse may come even with her Lady, and produce a Squire to attend on young Hercules, when he goes out to seek Adventures; that when his Master kills a Man, he may stand ready to pick his Pockets; and piously relieve his Aged Parents. Ah, Bromia, Bromia; if thou hadst been as handsome and as young as Phaedra; I say no more, but some-body might have made his Fortunes as well as his Master, and never the worse Man neither.

q.l: For, let the wicked World say what they please,
The fair Wife makes her Husband live at ease:
The Lover keeps him too; and but receives,
Like Jove, the remnants that Amphitryon leaves:
'Tis true, the Lady has enough in store,
To satisfie those two, and eke, two more:
In fine, the Man, who weighs the matter fully,
Wou'd rather be the Cuckold, than the Cully.

lg.l: I'M thinking, (and it almost makes me mad,)
How sweet a time, those Heathen Ladies had.
Idolatry, was ev'n their Gods own trade;
They Worshipt the fine Creatures they had made.
Cupid, was chief of all the Deities;
And Love was all the fashion, in the Skies.
When the sweet Nymph, held up the Lilly hand,
Jove, was her humble Servant, at Command.
The Treasury of Heav'n was ne're so bare,
But still there was a Pension for the Fair.
In all his Reign, Adultry was no Sin;
For Jove, the good Example did begin.
Mark, too when he usurp'd the Husband's name,
How civilly he sav'd the Ladies fame,
The secret Joys of Love, he wisely hid;
But you, Sirs, boast of more, than e'er you did.
You teize your Cuckolds; to their face torment 'em;
But Jove gave his, new Honours to content 'em,
And, in the kind remembrance of the Fair,
On each exalted Son, bestow'd a Star.
For those good deeds, as by the date appears,
His Godship, flourish'd full Two thousand Years.
At last, when He and all his Priests grew old,
The Ladies grew in their devotion cold;
And, that false Worship wou'd no longer hold.
Severity of Life did next begin;
(And always does, when we no more can Sin.)
That Doctrine, too, so hard, in Practice, lyes,
That, the next Age may see another rise.
Then, Pagan Gods, may, once again, succeed;
And Jove, or Mars, be ready, at our need,
To get young Godlings; and, so, mend our breed.

div.head: First Song, in the third Act.
div.p: CE— lia, that I once was Blest, is now the torment of— my Breast; Since to curse me you bereave me, of the plea- sure— I pos— sess't; Cru— el Creature to deceive me;— first— to Love and then to leave me; cru— el Creature to— de— ceive me,— first— to Love and— then to leave me;

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Had you the Bliss refus'd to grant,
I then had never known the want;
But possessing,
Once the Blessing,
Is the cause of my complaint:
Once possessing, is but tasting,
'Tis no Bliss that is not lasting.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Celia now is mine no more,
But I am hers and must adore;
Nor to leave her,
Will endeavour;
Charms that captiv'd me before
No unkindness can dissever;
Love that's true, is Love for ever.

div.head: The second Song, in the fourth Act.
div.p:
For I— ris I- sigh,— and— houre— ly dye, but— not for a— Lip,— nor a— languishing Eye;— she's
Fickle and false, and there we a— gree, O these— are the Vir— tues that Captivate me; we nei— ther be— leive what ei— ther can— say,— and nei— ther be— lei— ving, we— nei— ther be— tray, we— tray.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: 'Tis civill to Swear and say things of course,
We mean not the taking, for better for worse;
When present we Love, when absent agree,
I think not of Iris, nor Iris of me;
The Legend of Love, no couple can find,
So easy to part, and so easily joyn'd.

div.head: Last Song. A Dialogue betwixt Thyrsis and Iris.
div.p:
FAir I— ris and her Swain, were in a sha dy Bow'r, where Thyrsis long— in— Vain had sought the happy— hour: at length his hand advancing upon her Snowy Breast, he said; O kiss me longer, and— long— cryer, and long — er; if— you— will— make me blest:— an—
easy yeild-ing Maid, by trusting is un— done; our Sex is oft betray'd by— — grant— ing Love— too soon;— if you de— sire— to— — gain me, your suff'rings to re— dress, prepare to Love me lon— ger,— and— — long— er yet, and long— er,— be— fore you
[Thyrsis.] shall pos— sess: The lit— tle care you show, of all my sorrows past, makes Death appear too slow, and life— too long to— last. Fair I— ris— kiss me kindly,— in pit— ty of my Fate, and kind— ly still, and kind— ly— still,— before it be too late. You fond— ly court your bliss, and no advances
make, 'tis not for Maids to give, but 'tis for men to take: so you may kiss me kind— ly, and kindly still and kindly, and I will not re-bell; but doe not kiss and tell,— but doe not kiss and— tell,— no, ne— ver kiss and— tell.—
— Yes you may kiss me kind-ly,- and kindly still, and and may I kiss you kindly,— and— kindly still, and kindly, and— kindly still, and kindly, and I will not rebell. Yes you may kiss me kindly still, and will you not re— bell?— and may I kiss you kindly,— and kindly still, and
kindly still, and I will not re-bell; but doe not kiss and tell, but doe not kiss and kind-ly still, and you will not re— bell?— no, no,— no, no,— tell,— no, no,— no, no,— no, no,— no, no,— no, no, no, no,— I'le no, no, i'le never kiss and tell, no, no, i'le never kiss & tell, no, no, no, no, no, no, no,
never, never,— never— no never, never, never, no, never kiss and tell. I'le ne— ver, ne-ver, never, i'le never, never, never kiss and tell. [Chorus.] Thus at the height we Love and— live and fear not,— fear not— Thus at the height we Love and live and fear not— fear not—
to— be— poor;— We— give, and we— give, we— give and we— to be— poor; We give and we— give, we— give,— we give and we give till we can give no more:— give and we give,— and give till we can give no more:—
The first strain again. But what to day will take a— way, to morrow, to mor— row But what to day will take a— way, to morrow, to mor— row will re— store. will re— store.
